sections.content:

This document covers proposed standards and guidelines on writing PKGBUILDs for Fonts.

sections.title: Package naming
sections.content:
- TTF fonts: ttf-fontname
- OTF fonts: otf-fontname

If the font is a variable font, add the suffix -variable.

- The package name should be entirely lowercase.
- Ultimately there is no hard rule for font package naming, i.e. these are only guidelines. In general, package naming follows upstream. See also FS#77425.

sections.title: Package description
sections.content: The package description should at least contain the word font and what type of font it is: sans-serif, serif or monospace.

sections.title: Dependencies
sections.content: Fonts do not depend on anything. Many packages in the repositories, however, include fontconfig and xorg-mkfontscale as dependencies. Those were required when font packages needed to use install scripts to update the font cache – a lot of duplicate work now done by pacman hooks. If you install fontconfig or xorg-mkfontscale, all existing fonts in /usr/share/fonts/ will be cached making it unnecessary to force people to use fontconfig or mkfontscale.

sections.title: Provides
sections.content: Many applications rely on the virtual package ttf-font. If your font family meets the criteria, add provides=('ttf-font').

sections.title: Source
sections.content:
See whether a font is available from the following sources in this order:

- a code hosting platform like GitHub or an official website
- github.com/google/fonts (you should download individual files instead of cloning the repository, see ttf-roboto-mono for an example)
- Font Squirrel, Font Library, FFonts, 1001 Fonts, 1001 Free Fonts, DaFont

The following sites are not recommended:

- fonts.google.com (it no longer provides stable download URLs)
- FontSpace (checksums change for unknown reasons)

sections.title: Package
sections.content:
The following snippet is an example for an OTF font released under the SIL Open Font License 1.1 with Reserved Font Name:

```
license=('OFL-1.1-RFN')
...
package() {
  install -Dm644 -t "$pkgdir/usr/share/fonts/$pkgname" "path/to/font/*.otf"
  install -Dm644 -t "$pkgdir/usr/share/licenses/$pkgname" "path/to/license/OFL.txt"
}
```

- The OFL is technically a custom license, so each font package's license file needs to be installed under /usr/share/licenses/$pkgname.
- If the font contains many font files, consider using $pkgname instead of OTF for the destination directory.
